questions.question: The neural system of all animals is composed of highly specialised cells called:
questions.explanation: The neural system of all animals is composed of highly specialised cells called neurons that can detect, receive, and transmit different kinds of stimuli. (NCERT Page 239)

questions.question: The neural organisation is very simple in lower invertebrates like:
questions.explanation: The neural organisation is very simple in lower invertebrates like Hydra. (NCERT Page 239)

questions.question: The human neural system is divided into:
questions.explanation: The human neural system is divided into two parts: (i) the central nervous system (CNS) and (ii) the peripheral nervous system (PNS). (NCERT Page 239)

questions.question: The central nervous system (CNS) includes:
questions.explanation: The CNS includes the brain and the spinal cord and is the site of information processing and control. (NCERT Page 239)

questions.question: The peripheral nervous system (PNS) comprises:
options: All nerves of the body associated with CNS
questions.explanation: The PNS comprises of all the nerves of the body associated with the CNS (brain and spinal cord). (NCERT Page 239)

questions.question: The nerve fibres of the PNS are of two types:
questions.explanation: The nerve fibres of the PNS are of two types: (a) afferent fibres transmitting impulses from tissues/organs to the CNS and (b) efferent fibres transmitting regulatory impulses from the CNS to the concerned peripheral tissues/organs. (NCERT Page 239)

questions.question: Afferent nerve fibres transmit impulses from:
questions.explanation: Afferent fibres transmit impulses from tissues/organs to the CNS. (NCERT Page 239)

questions.question: Efferent nerve fibres transmit impulses from:
questions.explanation: Efferent fibres transmit regulatory impulses from the CNS to the concerned peripheral tissues/organs. (NCERT Page 239)

questions.question: The PNS is divided into:
questions.explanation: The PNS is divided into two divisions called somatic neural system and autonomic neural system. (NCERT Page 239)

questions.question: The somatic neural system relays impulses from CNS to:
questions.explanation: The somatic neural system relays impulses from the CNS to skeletal muscles. (NCERT Page 239)

questions.question: The autonomic neural system transmits impulses to:
options: Involuntary organs and smooth & cardiac muscles
questions.explanation: The autonomic neural system transmits impulses from the CNS to the involuntary organs and smooth & cardiac muscles. (NCERT Page 239)

questions.question: The autonomic neural system is further classified into:
questions.explanation: The autonomic neural system is further classified into sympathetic neural system and parasympathetic neural system. (NCERT Page 239)

questions.question: A neuron is the structural and functional unit of:
questions.explanation: A neuron is a microscopic structure composed of three major parts: cell body, dendrites, and axon. It is the structural and functional unit of the nervous system. (NCERT Page 240)

questions.question: The three major parts of a neuron are:
questions.explanation: A neuron is a microscopic structure composed of three major parts namely, cell body, dendrites, and axon. (NCERT Page 240)

questions.question: The cell body of a neuron contains:
options: Cytoplasm with cell organelles and Nissl granules
questions.explanation: The cell body contains cytoplasm with typical cell organelles and certain granular bodies called Nissl's granules. (NCERT Page 240)

questions.question: Nissl granules are composed of:
questions.explanation: Nissl's granules are composed of rough endoplasmic reticulum (RER) and are the site of protein synthesis. (NCERT Page 240)

questions.question: The short branching projections arising from the cell body of a neuron are called:
questions.explanation: Short fibres which branch repeatedly and project out of the cell body are called dendrites. (NCERT Page 240)

questions.question: The long fibre arising from the cell body of a neuron is called:
questions.explanation: The axon is a long fibre, the distal end of which is branched. (NCERT Page 240)

questions.question: The branched distal end of an axon is called:
questions.explanation: The axon is a long fibre, the distal end of which is branched. Each branch terminates as a bulb-like structure called synaptic knob. (NCERT Page 240)

questions.question: The bulb-like structures at the terminal end of axon branches are called:
questions.explanation: Each branch terminates as a bulb-like structure called synaptic knob which possess synaptic vesicles containing chemicals called neurotransmitters. (NCERT Page 240)

questions.question: Synaptic vesicles contain chemicals called:
questions.explanation: Synaptic knobs possess synaptic vesicles containing chemicals called neurotransmitters. (NCERT Page 240)

questions.question: Based on the number of axons and dendrites, neurons are classified as:
questions.explanation: Based on the number of axon and dendrites, the neurons are divided into three types, namely: multipolar (with one axon and two or more dendrites), bipolar (with one axon and one dendrite) and unipolar (cell body with one axon only). (NCERT Page 240)

questions.question: A multipolar neuron has:
options: One axon and two or more dendrites
questions.explanation: Multipolar neurons have one axon and two or more dendrites; found in the cerebral cortex. (NCERT Page 240)

questions.question: A bipolar neuron has:
options: One axon and two or more dendrites
questions.explanation: Bipolar neurons have one axon and one dendrite; found in the retina of eye. (NCERT Page 240)

questions.question: A unipolar neuron has:
options: Cell body with one axon only
questions.explanation: Unipolar neurons have cell body with one axon only; found in embryonic stage. (NCERT Page 240)

questions.question: Myelinated nerve fibres are found in:
questions.explanation: Two types of axons are found in the nervous system: myelinated and non-myelinated. The myelinated nerve fibres are enveloped with Schwann cells, which form a myelin sheath around the axon. They are found in spinal and cranial nerves. (NCERT Page 240)

questions.question: The myelin sheath is formed by:
questions.explanation: The myelinated nerve fibres are enveloped with Schwann cells, which form a myelin sheath around the axon. (NCERT Page 240)

questions.question: The gaps between two adjacent myelin sheaths are called:
questions.explanation: The gaps between two adjacent myelin sheaths are called nodes of Ranvier. (NCERT Page 240)

questions.question: Non-myelinated nerve fibres are found in:
questions.explanation: Non-myelinated nerve fibres are enclosed by a Schwann cell that does not form a myelin sheath around the axon, and are commonly found in autonomic and the somatic neural systems. (NCERT Page 240)

questions.question: The electrical potential difference across the resting plasma membrane of a neuron is called:
questions.explanation: The electrical potential difference across the resting plasma membrane, called as the resting potential. (NCERT Page 240)

questions.question: The resting potential of a neuron is approximately:
questions.explanation: The resting potential is about -70 mV, with the inner side of the membrane being negatively charged compared to the outer side. (NCERT Page 240)

questions.question: At resting state, the axonal membrane is:
questions.explanation: You might be aware that the axonal membrane is comparatively more permeable to potassium ions (K+) and nearly impermeable to sodium ions (Na+). Similarly, the membrane is impermeable to negatively charged proteins present in the axoplasm. Consequently, the axoplasm inside the axon contains high concentration of K+ and negatively charged proteins and low concentration of Na+. In contrast, the fluid outside the axon contains a low concentration of K+, a high concentration of Na+ and thus the membrane is positively charged outside and negatively charged inside. (NCERT Page 240)

questions.question: During depolarisation, the membrane becomes permeable to:
questions.explanation: When a stimulus is applied at a site, the membrane at that site becomes freely permeable to Na+. This leads to a rapid influx of Na+ followed by the reversal of the polarity at that site (the outer surface becomes negatively charged and inner side becomes positively charged). This is called depolarisation. (NCERT Page 241)

questions.question: During depolarisation, the potential changes from:
questions.explanation: During depolarisation, the potential changes from the resting potential of about -70 mV to about +30 mV as Na+ rushes in. (NCERT Page 241)

questions.question: The reversal of membrane potential during impulse transmission is called:
questions.explanation: The electrical potential difference across the plasma membrane at the site A is called the action potential, which is in fact termed as a nerve impulse. (NCERT Page 241)

questions.question: Repolarisation is achieved by:
questions.explanation: The membrane becomes freely permeable to K+, resulting in rapid efflux of K+ to the outside. This brings about repolarisation. (NCERT Page 241)

questions.question: The sodium-potassium pump:
options: Pumps Na+ out and K+ in
Pumps Na+ in and K+ out
questions.explanation: The ionic gradients across the resting membrane are maintained by the active transport of ions by the sodium-potassium pump which transports 3 Na+ outwards for 2 K+ into the cell. (NCERT Page 241)

questions.question: In myelinated neurons, impulse conduction is:
questions.explanation: In myelinated neurons, the impulse jumps from node to node. This is called saltatory conduction, which is faster than continuous conduction in non-myelinated fibers. (NCERT Page 241)

questions.question: A synapse is formed by:
options: Axon terminal of one neuron and dendrite or cell body of another
questions.explanation: A synapse is formed by the membranes of a pre-synaptic neuron and a post-synaptic neuron, which may or may not be separated by a gap called synaptic cleft. (NCERT Page 241)

questions.question: The gap between pre-synaptic and post-synaptic neurons is called:
questions.explanation: The pre-synaptic membrane and post-synaptic membrane may or may not be separated by a gap called synaptic cleft. (NCERT Page 241)

questions.question: At a chemical synapse, the signal is transmitted by:
questions.explanation: At a chemical synapse, the neurotransmitters are released from synaptic vesicles in the pre-synaptic neuron which bind to receptors on the post-synaptic membrane to transmit the signal. (NCERT Page 241)

questions.question: An example of a neurotransmitter is:
questions.explanation: Acetylcholine is an important neurotransmitter released at neuromuscular junctions and many synapses. (NCERT Page 241)

questions.question: The human brain is protected by the:
questions.explanation: The brain is protected by the skull and is covered by three meninges: dura mater (outer), arachnoid (middle), and pia mater (inner). (NCERT Page 242)

questions.question: The three meninges that cover the brain are:
options: Dura mater, arachnoid, and pia mater
questions.explanation: The brain is covered by three cranial meninges: an outer dura mater, a very thin middle arachnoid, and an inner pia mater. (NCERT Page 242)

questions.question: The space between the arachnoid and pia mater is filled with:
questions.explanation: The brain can be divided into three major parts: forebrain, midbrain and hindbrain. Between the arachnoid and pia mater is the subarachnoid space filled with cerebrospinal fluid. (NCERT Page 242)

questions.question: The brain can be divided into three major parts:
options: Gray matter, white matter, and ventricles
questions.explanation: The brain can be divided into three major parts: (i) forebrain, (ii) midbrain, and (iii) hindbrain. (NCERT Page 242)

questions.question: The forebrain consists of:
questions.explanation: Forebrain consists of cerebrum, thalamus and hypothalamus. (NCERT Page 242)

questions.question: The cerebrum is the largest part of the brain and is divided into:
questions.explanation: Cerebrum forms the major part of the human brain. A deep cleft divides the cerebrum longitudinally into two halves, which are termed as the left and right cerebral hemispheres. (NCERT Page 242)

questions.question: The two cerebral hemispheres are connected by:
questions.explanation: The two cerebral hemispheres are connected by a tract of nerve fibres called corpus callosum. (NCERT Page 242)

questions.question: The outer layer of the cerebral hemisphere is called:
questions.explanation: The layer of cells which covers the cerebral hemisphere is called cerebral cortex and is thrown into prominent folds. The cerebral cortex is referred to as the grey matter due to its greyish appearance. (NCERT Page 242)

questions.question: The folds of the cerebral cortex are called:
questions.explanation: The cerebral cortex is thrown into prominent folds. The uplifted ridges are called gyri (singular: gyrus). (NCERT Page 242)

questions.question: The grooves between the folds of the cerebral cortex are called:
questions.explanation: The grooves between the folds are called sulci (singular: sulcus). (NCERT Page 242)

questions.question: The inner part of the cerebral hemisphere containing myelinated nerve fibres is called:
questions.explanation: The inner part of cerebral hemisphere is called the white matter because it contains myelinated nerve fibres. (NCERT Page 242)

questions.question: The sensory area of the cerebrum is located in:
questions.explanation: The cerebrum has sensory areas known as sensory areas which receive sensory impulses. The primary sensory area is in the parietal lobe. (NCERT Page 242)

questions.question: The motor area of the cerebrum is located in:
questions.explanation: The motor area which controls voluntary muscle movements is located in the frontal lobe. (NCERT Page 242)

questions.question: The association areas in the cerebrum are responsible for:
options: Complex functions like memory, communication, and intersensory associations
questions.explanation: Association areas are responsible for complex functions like memory, intersensory associations, communication, and motor reasoning. (NCERT Page 242)

questions.question: The thalamus is a major:
options: Coordinating centre for sensory and motor signalling
questions.explanation: The thalamus is the major coordinating centre for sensory and motor signalling. (NCERT Page 242)

questions.question: The hypothalamus contains centres for:
options: Hunger, thirst, sleep-wake cycle, and body temperature
questions.explanation: Hypothalamus contains a number of centres which control body temperature, urge for eating and drinking. It also contains several groups of neurosecretory cells, which secrete hypothalamic hormones. (NCERT Page 242)

questions.question: The limbic system is involved in:
options: Regulation of sexual behaviour, expression of emotions, and motivation
questions.explanation: The inner parts of cerebral hemispheres and a group of associated deep structures like amygdala, hippocampus, etc., form a complex structure called the limbic system. Along with the hypothalamus, it is involved in the regulation of sexual behaviour, expression of emotional reactions (e.g., excitement, pleasure, rage and fear), and motivation. (NCERT Page 242)

questions.question: The midbrain is located between:
questions.explanation: The midbrain is located between the thalamus/hypothalamus of the forebrain and pons of the hindbrain. (NCERT Page 243)

questions.question: The dorsal portion of the midbrain consists of four round swellings called:
questions.explanation: The dorsal portion of the midbrain consists mainly of four round swellings (lobes) called corpora quadrigemina. (NCERT Page 243)

questions.question: The hindbrain comprises:
questions.explanation: Hindbrain comprises pons, cerebellum, and medulla (also called the medulla oblongata). (NCERT Page 243)

questions.question: The cerebellum is responsible for:
questions.explanation: Cerebellum has very convoluted surface in order to provide the additional space for many more neurons. It is responsible for maintaining body equilibrium and posture and coordination of voluntary movements. (NCERT Page 243)

questions.question: The medulla oblongata contains centres for:
options: Respiration, cardiovascular reflexes, and gastric secretions
questions.explanation: Medulla contains centres which control respiration, cardiovascular reflexes, and gastric secretions. (NCERT Page 243)

questions.question: The brain stem consists of:
questions.explanation: The midbrain, pons and medulla together constitute the brain stem. (NCERT Page 243)

questions.question: The spinal cord is enclosed in the:
questions.explanation: The spinal cord is a long cylindrical structure extending from the medulla oblongata to the lumbar region of the vertebral column, enclosed in the vertebral column. (NCERT Page 243)

questions.question: In a cross-section of the spinal cord, the gray matter is:
options: In the shape of H or butterfly in the centre
questions.explanation: In transverse section, the spinal cord shows two distinct regions: the inner grey matter and the outer white matter. The grey matter is arranged in the form of H or butterfly. (NCERT Page 243)

questions.question: The dorsal horn of the spinal cord gray matter contains:
questions.explanation: The dorsal horn (or posterior horn) contains cell bodies of interneurons and receives sensory information. (NCERT Page 243)

questions.question: The ventral horn of the spinal cord gray matter contains:
questions.explanation: The ventral horn (or anterior horn) contains cell bodies of motor neurons whose axons leave via ventral roots. (NCERT Page 243)

questions.question: A reflex action is:
options: An involuntary, automatic response to a stimulus
questions.explanation: Reflex action is a sudden, involuntary response to a stimulus. The reflex action involves the neural pathway called reflex arc. (NCERT Page 243)

questions.question: The pathway involved in a reflex action is called:
questions.explanation: The reflex action involves the neural pathway called reflex arc which includes receptor → afferent nerve → CNS → efferent nerve → effector. (NCERT Page 243)

questions.question: The correct sequence of components in a reflex arc is:
options: Effector → Afferent nerve → CNS → Efferent nerve → Receptor
Receptor → Afferent nerve → CNS → Efferent nerve → Effector
questions.explanation: The components of a reflex arc in sequence are: Receptor → Afferent (sensory) nerve → CNS (integration centre) → Efferent (motor) nerve → Effector (muscle or gland). (NCERT Page 243)

questions.question: Withdrawal of hand on touching a hot object is an example of:
questions.explanation: Withdrawal of hand on touching a hot object is a classic example of spinal reflex, which is controlled by the spinal cord without involvement of the brain. (NCERT Page 243)

questions.question: The human eye is a:
questions.explanation: The eye is the sense organ of sight and functions as a photoreceptor detecting light stimuli. (NCERT Page 244)

questions.question: The wall of the eyeball is composed of three layers:
questions.explanation: The wall of the eye ball is composed of three layers. The external layer is composed of a dense connective tissue, the sclera. The middle layer is the choroid. The inner layer is the retina. (NCERT Page 244)

questions.question: The transparent anterior portion of the sclera is called:
questions.explanation: The anterior portion of the sclera is called the cornea. It is transparent and admits light into the eye. (NCERT Page 244)

questions.question: The coloured visible portion of the eye containing the pupil is called:
questions.explanation: The anterior portion of the choroid is called the iris which is the visible coloured portion of the eye. The pupil is the aperture in the centre of the iris. (NCERT Page 244)

questions.question: The lens of the eye is held in position by:
questions.explanation: The lens is held in position by suspensory ligaments (zonule of Zinn) attached to the ciliary body. (NCERT Page 244)

questions.question: The space between the cornea and the lens is called:
questions.explanation: The space between the cornea and the lens is called the aqueous chamber and contains a thin watery fluid called aqueous humor. (NCERT Page 244)

questions.question: The space behind the lens is called:
questions.explanation: The space behind the lens is called the vitreous chamber and is filled with a transparent gel called vitreous humor. (NCERT Page 244)

questions.question: The photoreceptor cells in the retina are of two types:
questions.explanation: The neural layer of the retina contains three types of neural cells – from inside to outside – ganglion cells, bipolar cells, and photoreceptor cells. There are two types of photoreceptor cells, namely, rods and cones. (NCERT Page 244)

questions.question: Rods contain a purple-red pigment called:
questions.explanation: The rods contain the purplish-red protein called rhodopsin or visual purple. (NCERT Page 244)

questions.question: Cones are responsible for:
questions.explanation: Cones are responsible for daylight (photopic) vision and colour perception. They contain photopigments called iodopsins. (NCERT Page 244)

questions.question: The point where the optic nerve leaves the eye is called:
questions.explanation: At the point where the optic nerve leaves the eye and where blood vessels enter, there are no photoreceptors. This is called the blind spot. (NCERT Page 244)

questions.question: The fovea is the region of:
questions.explanation: At the posterior pole of the eye, lateral to the blind spot, there is a yellowish pigmented spot called macula lutea with a central pit called the fovea. The fovea is a thinned-out portion of the retina where only cones are densely packed. (NCERT Page 244)

questions.question: The ear performs two functions:
options: Hearing and maintenance of body balance
questions.explanation: The ears perform two sensory functions, hearing and maintenance of body balance. (NCERT Page 245)

questions.question: The three parts of the human ear are:
options: External ear, middle ear, and internal ear
questions.explanation: The ear can be divided into three sections – external ear, middle ear, and internal ear. (NCERT Page 245)

questions.question: The external ear consists of:
questions.explanation: The external ear consists of the pinna and external auditory meatus (canal). (NCERT Page 245)

questions.question: The tympanic membrane (eardrum) separates the:
questions.explanation: The tympanic membrane separates the external ear from the middle ear. (NCERT Page 245)

questions.question: The middle ear contains three small bones called:
questions.explanation: The middle ear contains three ossicles called malleus, incus, and stapes which are attached to one another in a chain-like fashion. (NCERT Page 245)

questions.question: The Eustachian tube connects the:
questions.explanation: An Eustachian tube connects the middle ear cavity with the pharynx. The Eustachian tube helps in equalising the pressures on either side of the ear drum. (NCERT Page 245)

questions.question: The internal ear is also called:
questions.explanation: The inner ear (internal ear) consists of the bony labyrinth and the membranous labyrinth. (NCERT Page 245)

questions.question: The coiled portion of the membranous labyrinth called cochlea is involved in:
questions.explanation: The coiled portion of the labyrinth is called cochlea. It contains the organ of hearing, the Organ of Corti. (NCERT Page 245)

questions.question: The sensory receptor for hearing is located in the:
questions.explanation: The Organ of Corti is the sensory organ of hearing located on the basilar membrane within the cochlea. (NCERT Page 245)

questions.question: The vestibular apparatus comprises:
options: Three semicircular canals and the otolith organ
questions.explanation: The vestibular apparatus is composed of three semi-circular canals and the otolith organ (utricle and saccule). They are involved in balance and posture. (NCERT Page 245)

questions.question: The semicircular canals are responsible for:
questions.explanation: The semicircular canals are involved in the detection of rotational movements and help maintain dynamic equilibrium. (NCERT Page 245)
